title: Lighting Techniques Database
description: Professional lighting setups and techniques for cinematic emotion conveyance

techniques.name: Rembrandt Lighting
techniques.description: Key light at 45° angle and height creates characteristic triangle of light on shadow-side cheek

key_light.position: 45° to side of subject, above eye level

back_light.intensity: Equal to or slightly brighter than key

techniques.emotional_effect: Drama, mystery, depth, classic portraiture, seriousness
techniques.typical_usage: Character portraits, serious moments, dramatic reveals, classic cinema
techniques.technical_notes: Triangle of light on cheek should be no larger than eye length. Named after Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn. Very flattering to most faces.

techniques.name: Butterfly Lighting
techniques.description: Key light directly in front and above subject creates butterfly-shaped shadow under nose

key_light.position: Directly above and in front, on camera axis

fill_light.position: Below subject, reflector or soft light

techniques.emotional_effect: Glamour, beauty, classic Hollywood, elegance, flattering
techniques.typical_usage: Beauty shots, glamour photography, Old Hollywood portraits, fashion
techniques.avoiding: Gritty realism, character flaws, harsh truth
techniques.technical_notes: Creates butterfly-shaped nose shadow. Hides wrinkles and blemishes. Emphasizes cheekbones. Can look flat if not careful with fill.

techniques.name: Split Lighting
techniques.description: Key light at exactly 90° to subject, lighting half face while other half in shadow
techniques.emotional_effect: Duality, internal conflict, split personality, good vs evil, dramatic tension
techniques.typical_usage: Characters with dual nature, noir films, moments of moral conflict, dramatic emphasis
techniques.avoiding: Soft romance, comedy, cheerful scenes, flattering beauty shots
techniques.technical_notes: Exactly half face lit, half dark. Very dramatic and bold. Works best in profile or near-profile. Don't overuse or loses impact.

techniques.name: Loop Lighting
techniques.description: Key light slightly off-center creates small shadow loop from nose toward cheek

key_light.position: 15-30° to side, slightly above eye level

techniques.typical_usage: Most dialogue scenes, standard portraits, general purpose lighting, interviews
techniques.avoiding: Extreme stylization, when dramatic effect needed
techniques.technical_notes: Most common portrait lighting. Between Rembrandt and Butterfly. Nose shadow should loop down but not touch cheek. Very versatile and flattering.
film_examples: Most modern films use this as default

techniques.name: Broad Lighting
techniques.description: Subject's face turned away from camera, key light illuminates side facing camera (wider side)

key_light.position: On same side as face is turned

techniques.emotional_effect: Makes face appear wider, more open, less dramatic
techniques.typical_usage: Subjects with narrow faces, when wider look desired, less dramatic scenes
techniques.avoiding: Subjects with wide faces, dramatic emphasis, slimming effect needed
techniques.technical_notes: Illuminates more of face than short lighting. More common in commercial work. Less dramatic than short lighting.

techniques.name: Short Lighting
techniques.description: Subject's face turned away from camera, key light illuminates side turned away (narrower side visible)
techniques.typical_usage: Dramatic scenes, slimming effect, adding mystery, more cinematic look
techniques.avoiding: Cheerful scenes, when want open feeling, faces needing widening
techniques.technical_notes: Illuminates less of face than broad lighting. More dramatic and sculptural. Slims face. More common in dramatic cinema.

techniques.name: Chiaroscuro
techniques.description: Extreme contrast between light and dark with bold shadows and minimal fill

key_light.position: Single strong source, often 45-90° to side

techniques.emotional_effect: Dramatic intensity, good vs evil, theatrical, religious, moral weight
techniques.typical_usage: Religious scenes, moral dramas, expressionist films, superhero moments, operatic scenes
techniques.avoiding: Realism, subtle drama, modern naturalism, comedy
techniques.technical_notes: Italian for 'light-dark'. Inspired by Caravaggio paintings. No fill light. Bold, theatrical shadows. Very striking but can be heavy-handed.
film_examples: The Passion of Joan of Arc

techniques.name: Silhouette Lighting
techniques.description: Subject backlit with no front lighting, appearing as dark shape against bright background
techniques.emotional_effect: Mystery, anonymity, dramatic reveal setup, universality, isolation
techniques.typical_usage: Mystery characters before reveal, sunset/sunrise shots, dramatic entrances, transitions
techniques.avoiding: When character emotion must be visible, intimate moments, dialogue scenes
techniques.technical_notes: Expose for bright background. Subject becomes pure shape. Very dramatic. Often used in transitions or introductions.
film_examples: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

techniques.name: Top Lighting (Horror)
techniques.description: Key light directly above subject creates deep shadows in eye sockets and under nose/chin
techniques.emotional_effect: Sinister, evil, unnatural, horror, skull-like, demonic
techniques.typical_usage: Horror films, villain reveals, demonic possession, unnatural states
techniques.avoiding: Flattering shots, romance, heroic moments, standard drama
techniques.technical_notes: Mimics overhead streetlight or interrogation room. Creates skull-like shadows. Very unflattering. Use sparingly for shock value.

techniques.name: Under Lighting
techniques.description: Light source below subject's face, pointing upward
techniques.emotional_effect: Unnatural, ghostly, campfire stories, sinister, scary
techniques.typical_usage: Campfire scenes, flashlight under chin, ghost stories, horror moments
techniques.technical_notes: Reverses natural lighting (sun from above). Creates unnatural, scary effect. Classic campfire/flashlight horror technique.

techniques.name: Natural Window Light
techniques.principle: Large soft light source from window provides beautiful, natural illumination

key_light.position: Window (natural light), subject perpendicular or angled to window
key_light.distance: Subject close to window for soft light

fill_light.position: Reflector or ambient bounce opposite window

techniques.typical_usage: Intimate dramas, realistic scenes, morning scenes, contemplative moments
techniques.avoiding: Night scenes, when consistent lighting needed, bright day exteriors (too harsh)
techniques.technical_notes: Diffused window light is one of most beautiful light sources. North-facing window = consistent. Overcast day = huge softbox. Close to window = softer.

techniques.name: Practical Light Motivation
techniques.description: Visible light sources in frame (lamps, candles, screens) motivate and enhance lighting design

practical_lights.position: In frame, visible (table lamps, candles, TVs, etc.)

augmentation.position: Hidden film lights matching practical source direction/quality
augmentation.intensity: Higher than practical to actually light scene

techniques.typical_usage: Modern cinematography, intimate interiors, night scenes, realistic drama
techniques.avoiding: When practicals would be distracting or inappropriate to story
techniques.technical_notes: Practical light alone rarely enough. Supplement with hidden film lights matching practical's quality/direction. Adds huge realism when done well.

hard_light.characteristics: Sharp shadow edges, high contrast, defined transitions
hard_light.sources: Small lights, direct sun, spotlights, unmodified fixtures

soft_light.characteristics: Gradual shadow transitions, lower contrast, wrapping quality
soft_light.sources: Large sources, diffused lights, softboxes, overcast sky, bounced light
soft_light.hardening_methods: Smaller source, remove diffusion, increase distance, grid

warm_light.usage: Interiors, memories, cozy scenes, golden hour

neutral_light.sources: Daylight, HMI lights, midday sun, flash
neutral_light.usage: Exteriors, neutral scenes, accurate color reproduction

cool_light.sources: Overcast sky, blue hour, moonlight (perceived), screens
cool_light.usage: Sci-fi, hospitals, night scenes, emotional distance

sources: Cinematography: Theory and Practice by Blain Brown
Light Science & Magic by Fil Hunter
Set Lighting Technician's Handbook by Harry Box
Painting with Light by John Alton
metadata.usage_notes: Lighting ratios indicate key:fill relationship (e.g., 4:1 = key is 4x brighter than fill). Contrast levels: low (<3:1), medium (3:1-6:1), high (6:1-12:1), extreme (12:1+). Quality (hard/soft) and color temperature are as important as setup geometry.
